title: No-deal, hard border threat to Irish tourism
text:
“Tourism is a sector that has already begun to feel the effects of Brexit,” Shane Ross, the Irish Tourism Minister, told The Australian Financial Review.

“Since the [2016] UK Referendum result, the weakening Sterling has meant that revenue from British visitors this year is likely to be over €100 million less than it was in 2016.”

In its 2020 budget, announced early this month, the government set aside €40 million in emergency funds to support tourism, as part of a broader spending hike to prepare the country for a no-deal Brexit.

“A no-deal Brexit would mean a worsening of the situation for tourism,” Mr Ross said. “Sterling would be likely to weaken further and other negatives are also likely to materialise.”

Economic uncertainty in other EU countries will further dent inbound tourism to Ireland, while a favourable euro-pound exchange rate will make Britain an even more competitive alternative destination.

Mr Ross said both the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland would suffer from loss of tourism, and warned that a hard border would discourage overseas tourists who did visit the Republic from exploring Ulster, and vice-versa.

Niall Gibbons, CEO of Tourism Ireland, said: “[This year's] figures underline a continuing weak trend and reflect feedback from industry partners on the ground who have been experiencing weaker demand. The uncertainty around Brexit is an ongoing challenge.”

In the small towns and villages that rely heavily on seasonal tourism, the mood is even more gloomy on the ground.

Advertisement

Peter O’Sullivan, a butcher in the picturesque village of Sneem on the popular Ring of Kerry tourist route in Ireland’s south-west, says the number of British visitors to the area has fallen by 50 per cent this year.

He's the third-generation to run the family business, which has won a string of awards for its black pudding and home-made sausages.

“We've seen a big fall-off in 2019,” Mr O’Sullivan said. “Brexit is not a good idea. Apart from affecting tourism, people see it as putting up a fence between our neighbour and our closest trading nation.

“Farming is a big part of this community and if you don’t have an outlet for your produce you are going to be in trouble aren’t you?”

The village of Adare, 20 kilometres south of Limerick, is renowned for its quaint thatched cottages. Shopkeepers there are also complaining about a drop in tourist traffic.

“Last season we were taking €4000 or €5000 a day; this year we would be lucky to

put through €1000,” one shop assistant said. “The buses are coming in but there are 10 people in the buses rather than 30. Brexit is a disaster; it should never have happened.”

For more on Josephine McKenna's tour through Ireland, see Sophisticated Traveller, out in the The Australian Financial Review on October 18.
description: As Boris Johnson goes for broke to seal a last-minute Brexit deal, Ireland is already counting the tourism cost of no deal - to the tune of about $620 million  year.
